results.title: Royal road
results.creator_credit: Raymond Perrin, British Council and British Movietone News
results.brief_description: A war-time newsreel study of King and Queen of England [George VI] carrying out their duties as sovereigns, visiting the blitzed areas of England during World War II.

results.title: Morning paper
results.creator_credit: Darrel Catling, Donald Carter, H. Bruce Woolfe and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: The story of a newspaper during wartime. Shows how the news is gathered and prepared for the press in spite of the threat of bombs. Describes the composition and checking of the pages, the creation of curved steroes to fit the rotary presses and various other tasks that must be completed before the paper can be put to bed.

results.title: The People's land
results.creator_credit: Ralph Keene, Donald Taylor and Strand Films
results.brief_description: In Britain the National Trust has acqired a number of estates and areas of land of historical interest: they include ancient castles, such as the 14th century Bodian castle, a Chiltern village, the famous valley of Dovedale, a number of prehistoric stone circles, 14,000 acres of Westmorland countryside and an extensive area of downland in Sussex. These estates and landmarks are held in public trust forever.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ralph Keene, Donald Taylor and Strand Films

results.title: Queen cotton
results.creator_credit: C Beaumont, Cecil Musk and Merton Park
results.brief_description: Looks at the cotton industry in Lancashire which, in the middle of this century, supplied most of the world with cotton goods. Features cranes on the docks in Manchester unloading cotton from all over the world to supply the looms of Lancashire. Includes a fashion shows highlighting cotton fabrics used by well-known British designers. Photographed by Jimmy Rogers, music by William Alwyn and editing by C. Beaumont.

results.title: Hollywood Costume. Inside the wardrobe: panel discussion
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI

video_links.name: Hollywood Costume. Inside the wardrobe: panel discussion

results.brief_description:
This panel discussion explores the collaborative process between film director and costume designer, the link between costume and character and how costumes connect audiences with on-screen worlds. It also focuses on the artistic role of costuming in the filmmaking process.

Hear from leaders in costuming, film and fashion, the influential Australian film and television costumers Edie Kurzer (‘South Solitary’, ‘Look Both Ways’, ‘Matching Jack’) Cappi Ireland (‘I Frankenstein’, ‘Animal Kingdom’, ‘The Slap’) and Anna Borghesi (‘Mao’s Last Dancer’, ‘Ned Kelly’ ,’Romper Stomper’) in a discussion chaired by NIDA’s Head of Costume, Fiona Reilly.

results.title: Hollywood Costume: Deborah Nadoolman Landis interview
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI

video_links.name: Hollywood Costume: Deborah Nadoolman Landis interview

results.brief_description:
Professor Deborah Nadoolman Landis, an Oscar nominated Hollywood costume designer (‘Raiders of the Lost Ark’, ‘Blues Brothers’, Michael Jackson’s ‘Thriller’) is the author of ‘Hollywood Costume’ (2012), the prize-winning catalogue for the exhibition, and ‘Hollywood Sketchbook: A Century of Costume Illustration’ (2012) among many other volumes. Landis received her Ph.D. from the Royal College of Art in London and is the Founding Director of the David C. Copley Center for Costume Design at the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television.
In this interview she talks about the origins of the Hollywood Costume industry, working as a costume designer, what a costume designer does and the relationship between the director and the costume designer.

results.title: Hollywood Costume: Interview with Jan Chapman and Janet Patterson
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
The 2009 film ‘Bright Star’ (directed by Jane Campion) tells the story of the romance between the English poet John Keats (1795 - 1821) and Fanny Brawne.
In this interview, ‘Bright Star’ producer Jan Chapman and costume designer Janet Patterson discuss the creative process behind costume design, and the design choices that went into making one of the costumes for the character Fanny Brawne (played in the film by Abbie Cornish).
The character’s crimson gown costume was on display during the ACMI Melbourne Winter Masterpieces ‘Hollywood Costume’ exhibition (2013).
Clips from ‘Bright Star’ (2009) courtesy of Hopscotch Films.

results.title: The Anzac Story
results.creator_credit: George I. Malcolm, Frank Hunter and ABC
results.brief_description: This video contains two programs pertaining to the history of the Anzacs using archival footage, drawings and stills and narrated by Barry Lineham. “Prelude to glory” - Presents a brief historical overview of Captain Cook’s landings in New Zealand and Australia and the following events which took place including colonisation, the chain of British governors, a Treaty with the Maoris, Federation in Australia, and the eventual lead up to World War I. With the advent of the War came the formation of the Anzac Corps, an alliance between the Australian and New Zealand defence forces, and a commitment by the Anzacs to fight for the British Empire in a war half a world away. Shows the sailing of the first convoy, the naval battle and sinking of the German battle ship “Emden” and the arrival of the Anzacs in Egypt. “Gallipoli” - Tells the story of this ill-fated war against the Turks, the tragic mistakes, the chaos and disorganisation, and the horrendous loss of young Anzacs (10,000 soldiers) from the botched up landing on 25 April 1915 in a small bay south of Ari Burnu (renamed Anzac Cove) to the eventual evacuation of all troops in December 1915.

results.title: Behind the menu
results.brief_description: A survey of the use of gas in commercial cooking and industrial establishments. The film includes glimpses of what happens “behind the menu” at establishments like the Menzies Hotel, The Royal Melbourne Hospital, the canteen at General Motors and a biscuit factory.

results.title: Warwick Thornton: Mother Courage interview
results.creator_credit: Jim Arneman, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
In this interview, Warwick talks about his early days in Alice Springs and getting his start in radio before moving on to films. Warwick also discusses the reoccurring theme of the matriarch in his works and the freedom and joy he finds in installation art.

‘Mother Courage’ is a film and sculptural installation by the internationally acclaimed artist and filmmaker Warwick Thornton. Co-commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA (13) as part of the ACMI Commissions Series, ‘Warwick Thornton: Mother Courage’ was a free exhibition in Gallery Two at ACMI 2013. As one of the most exciting filmmakers working in Australia today, Warwick Thornton is best known for ‘Samson & Delilah’, winner of the 2009 Camera d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival. His work, ‘Mother Courage’ (2012), is a dynamic, multi-screen art installation that features a dilapidated campervan as its centrepiece. Audiences will peer into the van’s grimy windows and through its rear doors, to view the provocative and poignant video contained within.
